Key Arguments: The Bill is an attack on freedom of speech and inconsistent with international human rights obligations.
It enables government and big tech to silence and censor speech beyond reasonable limits.
The Bill lacks mechanisms to protect valid expression of opinion and belief.
The definition of 'harm' is vague and could be weaponized to shut down legitimate speech.
There is no accountability for digital service providers' excessive policing of speech.
Government-authorized content is excluded, creating an asymmetrical rule for speech.
ACMA is given excessive powers that breach privacy.
The Bill lacks sufficient accountability and oversight for misuse of censorship powers.
Provisions for freedom of expression are tokenistic and do not meet international law standards.
Penalties for non-compliance are excessive and create a chilling effect on free speech.
Notable Quotes: The Bill will give government the power to silence religious and political speech that contradicts prevailing ideologies and political messaging.
The exclusion of government-authorised content from this censorship regime is hypocritical and inconsistent.
The severity of the penalties for failing to comply with the misinformation codes and standards... will provide a ‘chilling effect’ on free speech.
